bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Richard H. Creel, February 15, 1922

div1.p: [Carter] asks Creel for details of past Mississippi Valley outbreaks that were not yellow fever for a study he is conducting.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Richard H. Creel, February 15, 1922
div1.opener:
/LC
I. H. B.
Book
Creel
2121 California St., N. W.
, D. C.,
February 15, 1922.
Assistant Surgeon General R. H. Creel,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor Creel:
div1.p:
1/ Someone brought to my notice in the spring--I think of 1917--
a report of a disease suspected of being yellow fever in the Missis-
sippi Valley, but which I adjudged to be influenza. I think it was
you, who givae me the reports. I am not certain of the date--that is
the year. Do you recollect anything of it, and, if so, can you give
me any information on it?

2/ Armstrong, at one time a P. A Surgeon in this Service,
told me in the early spring of 1898 that he had seen quite an a-
mount of “infective jaundice” in the same section and that he had
made a report of it Bureau.

Can you refer this letter to the proper office to get a line on this
report of Armstrong's?

I am looking up epidemics characterized by jaundice, which
are not yellow fever and therefor am trying to get a line on this too.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General, (On Waiting Orders)
Address
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
